Where now is that sun of repose,</br>That once used to smile on this Breast,</br>On the Morn that so genially rose,</br>And at eve set so kindly in rest?
Alas!  all withdrawn from my sight,</br>On the Morning no longer it beams;</br>And, instead of contentment at night,</br>Spreads horror alone in my dreams.
O Belmour!  why e'er did I hear</br>What I knew must be death to believe?</br>Or drink up a strain with my ear,</br>When I saw it was meant to deceive?
To whom, tell me now, can I speak,</br>That will not reproach and exclaim?</br>And read through the blush on this cheek,</br>That guilt is the parent of shame?
In vain the dark grove do I try,</br>Some respite from censure to find;</br>But, Oh!  from a world I may fly,</br>Yet cannot escape from my mind!
In the thickest recess of the shade,</br>My conscience cries, "Flavia, see there,</br>What a wretch a fond father is made,</br>What a mother is plung'd in despair."
The Zephyr's most innocent gale</br>Now seems at my conduct to roar;</br>And the stream, as it winds through the dale,</br>Says, "Flavia is spotless no more."
At church, in the moment of pray'r,</br>Remorse lifts her terrible rod,</br>And harrows my soul with despair,</br>Though I kneel at the throne of my God.
'Tis just; — and I cannot upbraid,</br>For Belmour yet swells in my eye;</br>And this bosom, though basely betray'd,</br>Still heaves with too tender a sigh!
In spite of religion's pure breath,</br>The softest ideas will rise;</br>And I doat to distraction and death,</br>While I labour to hate and despise.
Come, grave, then, thou best of reliefs,</br>Regardless of season or time,</br>At once give an End to my griefs,</br>And a Lethe to wash o'er my crime.
Yet cease not, ye tears, still to flow</br>From the fount of contrition or love;</br>So th' excess of my sorrows below</br>May purchase my pardon above.</br>
